Psychedelic Intensity Scale

Tuesday, April 20 2021
·
12 min read
Josie Kins

This article does not represent an individual subjective effect component but instead serves to model the overall psychedelic experience as a systematic progression of seven levels. Each level of this system aims to both denote the various sensory, cognitive, and physical effects that can occur, as well as characterize the general intensity and feeling of the experience.

The substances which this intensity scale can apply to include, but are not limited to, both classical and research chemical psychedelics, such as:

LSD, Psilocybin mushrooms, DMT, Ayahuasca, Mescaline, 5-MeO-MiPT, 2C-B, LSA, AL-LAD, ALD-52, 1P-LSD, 2C-B-Fly, 2C-C, 2C-D, 2C-E, 2C-P, 4-AcO-DMT, 4-HO-MET, 4-HO-MiPT, 5-MeO-DMT, DPT, and DOC.

The approximate frequency of occurrence is also listed alongside each effect. For an explanation of the terms used within this frequency measuring system, please see the article here.

It should be noted that the specific effects listed within this levelling system may vary in their occurrence, style, and intensity across different substances and individuals. Nonetheless, this article still serves as an approximation for measuring the intensity of a person's psychedelic experience. For comparison between the various levels of psychedelic states versus the dissociative experience, please see our equivalent dissociative intensity scale.

This levelling system can be broken down into seven basic levels of intensity, which are described below.

Level 0

Sub-perceptual

-

A sub-perceptual psychedelic experience is the level at which the subjective effects produced by a psychedelic are not yet directly perceptible, meaning that they only exert a very slight change to a person's behaviour and senses. Dosages which exert effects of this intensity are often referred to as a "microdose".

Sub-perceptual dosages of psychedelics typically induce a small range of extremely faint cognitive effects which may be beneficial for enhancing a person's motivation, focus, and creativity. However, these changes may be difficult to distinguish between that of genuine alterations and the placebo effect.

The specific sub-perceptual effects which generally occur at this level of intensity are described and documented within their own dedicated articles, each of which are listed below.

Cognitive

  • Analysis enhancement (common)
  • Conceptual thinking (common)
  • Creativity enhancement (common)
  • Emotion enhancement (common)
  • Novelty enhancement (common)

Level 1

Subtle

-

A subtle psychedelic experience is the level at which the sensory, cognitive, and physiological effects produced by the substance first become apparent. A subtle experience is the level at which the visual, cognitive, and physical alterations produced by the substance first become distinctly beyond that of placebo, yet still mild enough to be easily be ignored with little effort by directing one's focus towards the external environment. The user may have to deliberately focus on the effects of the substance for them to be recognizable, or they may be slightly noticeable but will not insist upon the user's attention. While the effects are distinct enough to be noticed and identified, the person will still be in an essentially sober headspace.

Subtle doses of psychedelics typically induce a range of mild effects, which may include sensory enhancements such as color enhancement which makes colors look brighter and more saturated, sensory distortions such as visual drifting, cognitive effects such as focus enhancement or concentration impairment, and tactile effects such as paresthesia.

The specific subtle effects which generally occur at this level of intensity are described and documented within their own dedicated articles, each of which are listed below.

Visual

  • Colour enhancement (frequent)
  • Drifting (level 1-2 / frequent)
  • Geometry (level 1-2 / common)
  • Increased pareidolia (common)
  • Symmetrical texture repetition (common)
  • Tracers (level 1-2 / common)
  • Visual acuity enhancement (common)

Cognitive

  • Analysis enhancement (common)
  • Conceptual thinking (frequent)
  • Creativity enhancement (common)
  • Emotion intensification (common)
  • Increased music appreciation (common)
  • Novelty enhancement (frequent)
  • Wakefulness (frequent)

Other

  • Auditory enhancement (common)
  • Spontaneous bodily sensations (level 1-2 / common)

Level 2

Mild

-

A mild psychedelic experience is the level at which a person is slightly taken out of a purely sober headspace. A mild experience is the level at which the effects become noticeable and clearly distinct from sobriety while still partially remaining in the background of a person's awareness. At this level, the effects can be partially ignored by directing one's focus towards other stimuli, tasks, or the external environment. Depending on a person's experience with psychedelics, personality, and whether they are engaged in immersive activities, they may be able to suppress the effects, but someone who is embracing the experience will typically have a mild but noticeable alteration of their experience or understanding of the world around them.

Mild dosages of psychedelics typically induce a range of weak but noticeable effects, such as visual amplifications, visual distortions, cognitive amplifications, tactile sensations, and physical effects.

The specific mild effects which generally occur at this level of intensity are described and documented within their own dedicated articles, each of which are listed below.

Visual

  • Colour enhancement (frequent)
  • Drifting (level 1-2 / frequent)
  • Geometry (level 2-3 / common)
  • Increased pareidolia (common)
  • Symmetrical texture reptition (frequent)
  • Tracers (level 1-2 / frequent)
  • Visual acuity enhancement (frequent)

Cognitive

  • Analysis enhancement (frequent)
  • Conceptual thinking (frequent)
  • Creativity enhancement (frequent)
  • Emotion intensification (frequent)
  • Increased music appreciation (near universal)
  • Introspection (common)
  • Novelty enhancement (near universal)
  • Personal bias suppression (common)
  • Wakefulness (frequent)

Other

  • Auditory enhancements (common)
  • Nausea (common)
  • Spontaneous bodily sensations (level 1-2 / common)

Level 3

Moderate

-

A moderate psychedelic experience is the level at which a person takes on an overt, though not overwhelming, psychedelic headspace. A moderate experience is the level at which the effects and the nature of the substance become clear and defined enough that ignoring its action becomes difficult. At this level, the person will still generally just about be able to partake in regular behaviours and remain functional whilst maintaining the ability to communicate properly. Depending on the person's level of experience, the effects can be allowed to occupy a predominant role within the person's perception, or they may be ignored and made somewhat secondary to other chosen activities. At this level, people are typically able to engage in regular behaviours and maintain the ability to communicate properly, though there will likely be noticeable impairments in concentration and short term memory that may be overcome with effort.

Moderate dosages of psychedelics typically induce a range of well-defined effects, such as visual amplifications, visual distortions, complex geometric patterns, mild hallucinatory states, cognitive effects, tactile sensations, and physical effects.

The specific moderate effects which generally occur at this level of intensity are described and documented within their own dedicated articles, each of which are listed below.

Visual

  • Colour enhancement (frequent)
  • Drifting (level 2-3 / frequent)
  • Geometry (level 3-5 / common)
  • Increased pareidolia (frequent)
  • Internal hallucinations (level 1-2 / common)
  • Symmetrical texture repetition (common)
  • Tracers (level 2-3 / frequent)
  • Transformations (common)
  • Visual acuity enhancement (frequent)

Cognitive

  • Analysis enhancement (frequent)
  • Conceptual thinking (frequent)
  • Creativity enhancement (common)
  • Delusion (uncommon)
  • Emotion intensification (frequent)
  • Increased music appreciation (near universal)
  • Introspection (frequent)
  • Memory suppression (level 1-2 / common)
  • Novelty enhancement (frequent)
  • Personal bias suppression (common)
  • Spirituality enhancement (common)
  • Wakefulness (frequent)

Other

  • Auditory distortions (level 1-2 / common)
  • Auditory enhancement (common)
  • Auditory hallucinations (level 1-2 / uncommon)
  • Nausea (frequent)
    • Vomiting (common)
  • Spontaneous bodily sensations (level 2-3 / frequent)
  • Synaesthesia (rare)

Level 4

Strong

-

A strong psychedelic experience is the level at which a person is in a fully psychedelic headspace, though typically still with significant awareness of themself and their surroundings. A strong experience is the level at which the effects become powerful enough to render the person experiencing them mostly incapable of functioning, interacting normally, or thinking in a sober manner. At this level, the effects of the substance are clear and can no longer be ignored in any capacity, leaving the user entirely engaged in the experience whether they wish to be or not. At this level, a person may be disinclined to speak or may have voice patterns that are noticably different from their sober state. They may also be disinclined to engage in activities or have difficulty performing tasks. At this level, the effects of the substance can no longer be ignored in any capacity, leaving the user entirely engaged in the experience whether they wish to be or not.

Strong dosages of psychedelics typically induce a range of powerful effects, such as visual distortions which drastically alter the appearance of one's environment, indescribably complex geometric patterns which can almost entirely block out a person's environment, distinct hallucinatory states, disorientating cognitive effects, strong tactile sensations, and various physical effects.

The specific strong effects which generally occur at this level of intensity are described and documented within their own dedicated articles, each of which are listed below.

Visual

  • Autonomous entities (uncommon)
  • Colour enhancement (near universal)
  • Drifting (level 3-4 / near universal)
  • Geometry (level 5-6 / frequent)
  • Increased pareidolia (near universal)
  • Internal hallucinations (level 2-3 / common)
  • Symmetrical texture repetition (common)
  • Tracers (level 3-4 / frequent)
  • Transformations (common)
  • Visual acuity enhancement (frequent)

Cognitive

  • Analysis suppression (common)
  • Conceptual thinking (frequent)
  • Creativity enhancement (common)
  • Delusion (common)
  • Emotion intensification (near universal)
  • Increased music appreciation (near universal)
  • Introspection (frequent)
  • Memory suppression (level 2-3 / frequent)
  • Ego death (common)
  • Novelty enhancement (near universal)
  • Personal bias suppression (near universal)
  • Spirituality enhancement (common)
  • Thought disorganization (near universal)
  • Wakefulness (near universal)

Other

  • Auditory distortions (level 2-3 / common)
  • Auditory enhancement (common)
  • Auditory hallucinations (level 2-3 / common)
  • Nausea (frequent)
    • Vomiting (common)
  • Spontaneous bodily sensations (level 3-4 / common)
  • Synaesthesia (uncommon)

Level 5

Heavy

-

A heavy psychedelic experience is the level at which the practical upper limit of what the substance is capable of producing is reached. A heavy experience is the level at which the practical upper limit of what the substance is capable of producing is reached. At this level, the user will be rendered incapable of functioning and communicating properly, leaving them either completely disconnected from their environment or at least extremely disorientated. At this level, the user will be rendered incapable of functioning and communicating properly, leaving them either completely disconnected from their environment or extremely disorientated.

Heavy dosages of psychedelics typically induce a wide range of all-consuming effects, such as breaking through into a space which is comprised of unfathomably complex geometric patterns and hallucinatory states, a complete loss of the person's sense of self or ego, delusions, occasionally life-changing spiritual or transpersonal experiences, and powerful cognitive effects.

The specific heavy effects which generally occur at this level of intensity are described and documented within their own dedicated articles, each of which are listed below.

Visual

  • Autonomous entities (uncommon)
  • Colour enhancement (near universal)
  • Drifting (level 3-4 / frequent)
  • Geometry (level 6-7 / frequent)
  • Increased pareidolia (near universal)
  • Internal hallucinations (level 3-4 / frequent)
  • Symmetrical texture repetition (frequent)
  • Tracers (level 3-4 / frequent)
  • Transformations (frequent)
  • Visual acuity enhancement (frequent)

Cognitive

  • Analysis suppression (near universal)
  • Conceptual thinking (near universal)
  • Delusions (common)
  • Emotion intensification (near universal)
  • Increased music appreciation (near universal)
  • Introspection(near universal)
  • Memory suppression (level 3-4 / frequent)
  • Ego death (frequent)
  • Novelty enhanement (near universal)
  • Personal bias suppression (frequent)
  • Spirituality enhancement (common)
  • thought disorganization (frequent)
  • Unity and interconnectedness (uncommon)
  • Wakefulness (near universal)

Other

  • Auditory distortions (level 2-3 / frequent)
  • Auditory enhancement (common)
  • Auditory hallucinations (level 2-3 / common)
  • Machinescapes (uncommon)
  • Nausea (frequent)
    • Vomiting (common)
  • Spontaneous bodily sensations (level 3-4 / near universal)
  • Synaesthesia (uncommon)

Level 6

Extreme

-

An extreme psychedelic experience is the level at which the effects have become so powerful and pronounced that the person will typically be rendered unconscious and amnesic for a prolonged period of time, usually with highly exaggerated and uncomfortable physical side effects. An extreme experience is the level at which the effects have become so powerful and pronounced that the person will typically be rendered unconscious and amnesic for a prolonged period of time, usually with highly exaggerated and uncomfortable physical side effects. At this level, the person will experience the effects typically associated with the previously described heavy dosage during the onset and offset of their trip. During the peak, however, they will simply black out and become unconscious for a prolonged period of time that is directly proportional to the dosage consumed.

At this level, the person will experience the effects typically associated with the previously described heavy dosage during the onset and offset of their trip. During the peak, however, they will simply black out and become unconscious for a prolonged period of time that is directly proportional to the dosage consumed.

Although extreme psychedelic states may be attractive to certain individuals, it is worth noting that this level of intensity is not only potentially dangerous, but also less therapeutic and explorative than the previous levels.
